children.value: Previously, we have solved the classical Poisson equation, using a

.
If this approach produces good results in most cases, it has a major drawback.
Indeed, when using for instance 1st order Lagrange elements for the pressure

children.html: ppp
∇p\nabla p∇p

children.value:
is piecewise constant per element.
In particular, the normal flux is not conserved at the interface between two elements.
In the case of a mass flux, this means that the local mass balance is not necessarily satisfied.
Mass balanced is only ensured in an averaged sense.
When conductivity is low, this can lead to spurious oscillations in the solution, as we shall demonstrate hereafter.

(with pressure and flux both unknown) can solve this issue by using vector elements for the
flux which preserve the normal component of the flux between elements, ensuring local mass balance.
To illustrate the shortcomings of the primal formulation, we will produce an example leading to an oscillating solution.
Mixed formulation for the Poisson equation

children.label: Mixed formulation for the Poisson equation

children.value: We are looking to solve the following equation:

children.html: (E):{−κΔu=0 on Ω,u=u0 on ΓD,∂nu=0 on ΓN.(E): \left\{ \begin{aligned} -\kappa\Delta u &= 0 \ &\text{on }\Omega, \\ u &= u_0 \ &\text{on }\Gamma_D, \\ \partial_n u &= 0 \ &\text{on }\Gamma_N. \end{aligned} \right.(E):⎩⎨⎧​−κΔuu∂n​u​=0 =u0​ =0 ​on Ω,on ΓD​,on ΓN​.​

{∇‾⋅w‾=0 on Ω,w‾=−κ∇u‾ on Ω,u=u0 on ΓD,w=0 on ΓN.\left\{ \begin{aligned} \underline{\nabla}\cdot \underline{w} &= 0 \ &\text{on }\Omega, \\ \underline{w} &= -\kappa\underline{\nabla u} \ &\text{on }\Omega, \\ u &= u_0 \ &\text{on }\Gamma_D,\\ w &= 0 \ &\text{on }\Gamma_N. \end{aligned} \right.⎩⎨⎧​∇​⋅w​w​uw​=0 =−κ∇u​ =u0​ =0 ​on Ω,on Ω,on ΓD​,on ΓN​.​

children.label: Boundary conditions in the mixed formulation
